<article id="post-88167" class="post-88167 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-obama category-politics article-label-truth source-header-erumor-as-sample-seen-on-the-internet" itemscope itemtype="https://schema.org/Article">
<div class="td-a-rec td-a-rec-id-content_top "><div data-id="99988" id="truth-1846957448"><ins class="adsbygoogle" style="display:block
<div class="addthis_toolbox addthis_default_style addthis_32x32_style" addthis:url='https://www.truthorfiction.com/michelle-obama/' addthis:title='Questions about Michelle Obama' >

Michelle Obama, the wife of presidential candidate Barack Obama, has popped up in eRumors in 2008 about two issues.  One is that she is alleged to have said during the campaign that for the first time in her adult lifetime she is proud of her country.  There are also questions about why her graduate thesis from Princeton University has been classed as restricted until after November 5th, 2008, which is one day after the general election.

column2: For the first time in my        adult lifetime I am proud of my country?&#8221
column3:
-Truth!
 It was during speeches in Milwaukee and Madison, Wisconsin on February 18, 2008.

column2: People in this country are ready for change and hungry for a different kind of politics and … for the first time in my adult life I am proud of my country because it feels like hope is finally making a comeback.”

“For the first time in my adult lifetime, I’m really proud of my country … not just because Barack has done well, but because I think people are hungry for change.  I have been desperate to see our country moving in that direction and just not feeling so alone in my frustration and disappointment.”

column1: A spokesperson for the Obama Campaign, Jan Psake, said Michelle Obama was not trying to knock her country but rather to “
column2: underscore the meaning behind her husband&#8217
column5: The point is that of course Michelle is proud of her country, which is why she and Barack talk constantly about how their story wouldn’t be possible in any other nation on Earth.  What she meant is that she’s really proud at this moment because for the first time in a long time, thousands of Americans who’ve never participated in politics before are coming out in record numbers to build a grassroots movement for change.”

column1: Critics, however, seized upon her statement and wondered aloud why there would not be any other times in her adult life when she felt proud of her country.

column2:
s Princeton thesis been restricted for any public release until after November 5?-Previously Truth!  But it has now been released from restriction!

Princeton University released the thesis to the public on March 25, 2008, after criticism of the fact that it was being held for release until the day after the general election.

column1: The thesis was written under her maiden name, Michelle LaVaughn Robinson.  At Princeton, Michelle Obama focused on sociology and earned a certificate in African-American studies.

column2: Princeton-Educated Blacks and the Black Community.&#8221

column1: An article in the Daily Princetonian from March 26, 2008, quoted the thesis as examining “
column3: how the attitudes of black alumni have changed        over the course of their time at the University&#8221
column6: whether they will        become more or less motivated to benefit the black community.&#8221

column1: She surveyed 89 black graduates of Princeton and concluded from her research that “
column2: attending the University as an undergraduate decreased the        extent to which black alumni identified with the black community as a        whole.&#8221

column1: No explanation has been given for why the thesis was restricted for public access, although that can be requested by an alumnus.
A real example of the eRumor as it has appeared on the Internet:
<div class="addthis_toolbox addthis_default_style addthis_32x32_style" addthis:url='https://www.truthorfiction.com/michelle-obama/' addthis:title='Questions about Michelle Obama' >
Read past all the rhetoric to the part about Michelle Obama’
column2:
s Princeton thesis.  I find this alarming. 
 
 
         Michelle Obama, wife of Democrat frontrunner Barack Obama, shocked a lot of people recently when she said this: “
column3: For the first time        in my adult lifetime I am proud of my country.&#8221
column4: Wow! That takes my breath away.

column1: Mrs. Obama is 44 years old, so for over roughly 24 years of “
column3:
taking her at her word, she has never been proud of our nation.
 Is there a theme here? You may remember that last year Senator Obama said he refused to wear a flag lapel pin because it represented a “
column5: And what precisely is true patriotism? According to Senator Barack Hussein Obama, it is opposing the war in Iraq.

column1: Apparently nothing America did from 1982 to 2008 caused her heart to swell with pride. Not our successful effort to defeat Soviet communism and liberate millions of people in Eastern Europe? Not our relief efforts around the world, through which we spent billions to help the downtrodden?

Not anything? When she learned with all the rest of us how her fellow citizens on United Flight 93 bravely fought back against jihadist hijackers and prevented another disaster on September 11th, did she not fill up with pride?
As Americans of all races and classes rallied together in defense of our nation in the aftermath of September 11th, did her spirit not jump with love for her homeland? Apparently not.

The Obamas are living examples of the American Dream. Both Michelle Obama and her husband have Ivy League degrees. They make a joint income of over One Million Dollars a year. They live lives that most ordinary Americans
can only dream of.
Yet, Mrs. Obama, who wants to be First Lady, has  been unable to find the pride in America that millions of ordinary Americans feel every day.
Sadly, her attitude is not rare among leftwing American elites. We are “
column3: millions of Americans to be Globalists first and foremost, and we are doing precious little about educating our children to be Proud and Unashamed Americans.

column1: **The Obamas are flying high politically right now, but I don’
column2: t believe many Americans will want to cast their votes this November for a couple so out of touch with traditional American values.**
For the first time in my adult life, I am proud of my  country,&#8221
column5: What she meant was, this is the first time that she&#8217
column6: s been        proud of the politics of America,&#8221

column1: HOWEVER, nowhere in there does she leave space for, allude to, or specify a reference to American politics.

column2: s a Princeton and Harvard educated lawyer, and she can&#8217
column3: t specify between her country and its politics???

column5: Princeton-Educated Blacks and the        Black Community,&#8221

AUTHOR: Michelle LaVaughn Robinson (1985), Sociology Department ADVISOR: Not available
LOCATED AT: Mudd Library.
Michelle LaVaughn Robinson Obama lamented that white professors and classmates always saw her as “
column2: Black first and a student second.&#8221
column3: She had        surveyed alumni to see whether they sacrificed their commitment to other        blacks on the altar of success, and foresaw for herself an uneasy future:        &#8220
column4: further integration and/or assimilation into a White cultural and social        structure that will only allow me to remain on the periphery of society

column1: As Michelle Obama wrote in her thesis introduction, “
column2: My experiences at        Princeton have made me far more aware of my &#8216
column4: than ever before.        I have found that at Princeton no matter how liberal and open-minded some        of my White professors and classmates try to be toward me, I sometimes        feel like a visitor on campus

column1: Michelle Obama was guided in her choice of thesis  topic by a consuming concern that her success might compromise her black identity.
As she wrote in her conclusion: “
column2: I wondered whether or not my education at        Princeton would affect my identification with the Black community. I hoped        that these findings would help me conclude that despite the high degree        of  identification with Whites as a result of the  educational and        occupational path that Black Princeton alumni follow, the alumni would        still maintain a certain level of identification with the black community.        However, these findings do not support this possibility.&#8221
s fears of losing touch with her roots without ever being        embraced into the mainstream led her to promise, in her thesis        introduction, &#8220
column3: to actively utilize my resources to benefit the Black        community.&#8221

Her thesis is the ONLY one on the 449-result long list *restricted until a specific date: November 5th*.
